title: Tesla Model Y
content:
{{Short description|Battery electric car introduced in 2020}}
{{Use American English|date=September 2022}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2022}}
{{Infobox electric vehicle
| name = Tesla Model Y

  | United States: [[Fremont, California]] ([[Tesla Fremont Factory|Fremont Factory]]); [[Austin]] ([[Giga Texas]])<ref>{{Cite web|last=Carlson|first=Kara|title=Tesla's Austin factory started Model Y production late last year, company reveals|url=https://www.statesman.com/story/business/2022/01/26/tesla-austin-factory-begins-model-y-production-elon-musk-gigafactory-texas/6635563001/ |date=January 27, 2022 |access-date=February 18, 2022|website=Austin American-Statesman|language=en-US}}</ref>
  | China: [[Shanghai]] ([[Giga Shanghai]])
  | Germany: [[Grünheide (Mark)|Grünheide]] ([[Giga Berlin]])

| height = {{convert|63.9|in|mm|0|abbr=on}}
| weight = {{unbulleted list
  | {{cvt|3920|lb}}<ref>{{cite web |url=https://teslamodelywiki.com/tesla-model-y-specifications/#Tesla_Model_Y_Dimensions |title=Tesla Model Y Specifications |website=Tesla Model Y Wiki |access-date=March 11, 2020}}</ref> ({{abbr|SR RWD|Standard Range rear-wheel drive}})
  | {{cvt|4363|lb}} ({{abbr|AWD|all-wheel drive}})<ref name="official-2023"/>

}}

The '''Tesla Model Y''' is a [[battery electric vehicle|battery electric]] [[Compact crossover SUV|compact crossover]] manufactured by [[Tesla, Inc.]] Unveiled in March 2019,<ref name="electrek-2019-03-14">
{{Cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2019/03/14/tesla-model-y-electric-suv-unveil/
|title=Tesla unveils Model Y electric SUV with 300 miles range and 7-seats|last=Lambert|first=Fred
|date=March 15, 2019|website=[[Electrek]]|language=en-US|access-date=March 15, 2019
|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190315055454/https://electrek.co/2019/03/14/tesla-model-y-electric-suv-unveil/|archive-date=March 15, 2019|url-status=live}}
</ref> it started production at its [[Tesla Factory|Fremont plant]] in January 2020,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a30705862/tesla-production-results-q4-model-y/
|title=Tesla Beats Expectations, Declares a Profit, and Has Started Model Y Production |last=Baldwin |first=Roberto
|date=January 29, 2020| website=Car and Driver |publisher=Hearst |language=en-US |access-date=February 27, 2020 }}
</ref> and started deliveries on March 13, 2020.<ref name=":0" />

The Model Y is based on the [[Tesla Model 3|Model 3]] sedan platform.<ref name="Mashable-2016-01-29">{{cite news |url=https://mashable.com/2016/01/28/tesla-model-3-variants/|title=Tesla is working on multiple variations of the Model 3|first=Nick |last=Jaynes|date=January 29, 2016|access-date=March 15, 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205323/https://mashable.com/2016/01/28/tesla-model-3-variants/|archive-date=March 30, 2019|publisher=[[Mashable]]}}</ref> It shares an estimated 75 percent of its parts with the Tesla Model 3,<ref>{{Cite web|last=Lambert|first=Fred|date=April 8, 2020|title=Tesla Model Y teardown: shows some great improvements over Model 3 despite sharing 75% of parts|url=https://electrek.co/2020/04/08/tesla-model-y-teardown-improvements-over-model-3-sharing-parts/|access-date=October 28, 2020|website=Electrek|language=en-US}}</ref> which includes a similar interior and exterior design and electric powertrain. The Model Y fills a smaller and less expensive segment than the mid-sized [[Tesla Model X]].<ref name="electrek-2017-08-02">{{cite news|first=Fred |last=Lambert|date=August 2, 2017|title=Tesla Model Y is coming to market sooner using Model 3 architecture, says Elon Musk|publisher=electrek|url=https://electrek.co/2017/08/02/tesla-model-y-coming-sooner/|url-status=live|access-date=March 15, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205317/https://electrek.co/2017/08/02/tesla-model-y-coming-sooner/|archive-date=March 30, 2019}}</ref> Like the Model X, the Model Y offers optional third-row seats for a seven-passenger seating capacity.<ref name="MotorTrend-2019-03-15">{{cite magazine |first=Miguel |last=Cortina |date=March 15, 2019 |title=Tesla Model Y First Ride: A Compact Crossover For Canyon Roads |url=https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-model-y-first-ride/ |url-status=live |magazine=Motor Trend |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190320084459/https://www.motortrend.com/news/tesla-model-y-first-ride/ |archive-date=March 20, 2019 |access-date=March 15, 2019}}
</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=December 2, 2019 |title=Tesla Model Y: rare glimpse at third-row seats |url=https://electrek.co/2019/12/02/tesla-model-y-third-row-seats/ |access-date=February 27, 2020 |website=Electrek |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite tweet|number=1201513627292966913|user=Model3Owners|title=I took better pictures of the third row seats... sheesh|author=Online Tesla Owners|date=December 2, 2019|access-date=December 4, 2019|language=en}}</ref>

In the first quarter of 2023, the Model Y outsold the [[Toyota Corolla]] to become the world's best-selling car, the first ever electric vehicle to claim the title.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.motor1.com/news/669135/tesla-model-y-worlds-best-selling-car-q1-2023/ |title=Tesla Model Y Was The World's Best-Selling Car In Q1 2023 |first=Juan Felipe |last=Munoz |work=Motor1 |date=2023-05-25 |access-date=2023-05-26}}</ref>

==History==
{{cleanup rewrite|section=yes|date=June 2021}}

=== Pre-launch ===
[[File:Tesla 3 + Y.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Tesla Model 3 (left) and Tesla Model Y (right) side by side]]
In 2013, Tesla Motors filed to trademark "Model Y".<ref name=TT-2016-04-11>{{Cite news |url= http://www.techtimes.com/articles/148939/20160411/if-ford-did-not-block-trademark-for-model-e-tesla-would-have-completed-a-word-after-model-s-model-x.htm |title= If Ford Did Not Block Trademark For Model E, Tesla Would Have Completed A Word After Model S, Model X |date= April 11, 2016 |first=Santiago |last=Tiongco |work= Tech Times |access-date= March 15, 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205509/https://www.techtimes.com/articles/148939/20160411/if-ford-did-not-block-trademark-for-model-e-tesla-would-have-completed-a-word-after-model-s-model-x.htm |archive-date= March 30, 2019 |url-status= live }}</ref>

In 2015, [[Elon Musk]] teased a Model 3-based Model Y with [[Gull-wing door|falcon-wing doors]].<ref name=ars-2015-10-07>{{cite news |url= https://arstechnica.com/cars/2015/10/tesla-model-y-with-falcon-wing-doors-hinted-at-by-elon-musk/ |title= Elon Musk hints at Tesla Model Y with falcon-wing doors |first=Sebastian |last=Anthony |date= October 7, 2015 |work= [[art tech]] |access-date= March 15, 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330193150/https://arstechnica.com/cars/2015/10/tesla-model-y-with-falcon-wing-doors-hinted-at-by-elon-musk/ |archive-date= March 30, 2019 |url-status= live }}</ref>

In 2017, the Model Y's silhouette was teased to Tesla shareholders at the annual general meeting in June.<ref name=Guardian-2017-06-07>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jun/07/tesla-teases-new-model-y-car-cheaper-model-3-production-elon-musk |title= Tesla teases new Model Y car as cheaper Model 3 nears production |first=Samuel |last=Gibbs |date= June 7, 2020 |newspaper= [[The Guardian]] |access-date= March 15, 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330181733/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/jun/07/tesla-teases-new-model-y-car-cheaper-model-3-production-elon-musk |archive-date= March 30, 2019 |url-status= live }}</ref> Elon Musk also announced that the Model Y would be produced in a new factory, as it was not likely that the [[Tesla Factory|Fremont plant]] would have room to accommodate another production line.<ref name=WSJ-2017-06-06>{{cite news |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/tesla-ceo-elon-musk-signals-new-factory-for-model-y-suv-1496797117 |title= Tesla CEO Elon Musk Signals New Factory for Model Y SUV |first=Tim |last=Higgins |date= June 6, 2017 |newspaper= The Wall Street Journal |access-date= March 15, 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190316150723/https://www.wsj.com/articles/tesla-ceo-elon-musk-signals-new-factory-for-model-y-suv-1496797117 |archive-date= March 16, 2019 |url-status= live }}</ref>

In June 2018, a new silhouette was revealed by CEO Musk. With the new image, it was stated that the Model Y would be formally announced in March 2019.<ref name=Fortune-2018-06-06>{{cite news |url= http://fortune.com/2018/06/06/elon-musk-tesla-model-y-image/ |title= Elon Musk Shares a New Image of the Tesla Model Y |first=Lisa Marie |last=Segarra |date= June 6, 2018 |work= [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |access-date= March 15, 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330193202/http://fortune.com/2018/06/06/elon-musk-tesla-model-y-image/ |archive-date= March 30, 2019 |url-status= live }}</ref> The Model Y announcement had been planned for 2018; however, production problems with the Model 3 resulted in it being pushed to 2019.<ref name=Electrek-2018-10-22>{{cite web |url= https://electrek.co/2018/10/22/tesla-model-y/ |title= Tesla Model Y: what to expect? |first=Fred |last=Lambert |date= October 22, 2018 |publisher= Electrek |access-date= March 15, 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205319/https://electrek.co/2018/10/22/tesla-model-y/ |archive-date= March 30, 2019 |url-status= live }}</ref> In October 2018, Elon Musk revealed that he has approved the finalized design for the first production version of the Model Y, however production would not start until 2020.<ref name=Verge-2018-10-24>{{cite news |url= https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/24/18020936/teslas-model-y-crossover-prototype-production |title= Tesla's Model Y crossover is ready for production, Elon Musk says |first=Sean |last=O'Kane |date= October 24, 2018 |work= [[The Verge]] |access-date= March 15, 2019 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205340/https://www.theverge.com/2018/10/24/18020936/teslas-model-y-crossover-prototype-production |archive-date= March 30, 2019 |url-status= live }}</ref> On March 3, 2019, Elon Musk published multiple tweets, announcing the unveiling event and confirming some specifications.<ref name=Twitter-1102332778492772352>{{Cite tweet |first=Elon |last=Musk |user=elonmusk |number=1102332778492772352 |title=Model Y unveil event on March 14 at LA Design Studio |date=March 3, 2019|website=@elonmusk|language=en|access-date=March 4, 2019|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190303235845/https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1102332778492772352 |archive-date=March 3, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> Musk confirmed the vehicle would use standard doors, as opposed to the falcon-wing doors used on the Model X.<ref name=Twitter-1102340302663180288>{{Cite tweet |first=Elon |last=Musk |user=elonmusk |number=1102340302663180288 |title=Normal |date=March 3, 2019 |language=en |access-date=March 4, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190407170743/https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1102340302663180288 |archive-date=April 7, 2019 |url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Release ===
On March 14, 2019, Elon Musk premiered the Tesla Model Y at an event at Tesla's design studio in Hawthorne, CA, where specifications were announced and the vehicle was shown. Test drives of multiple Model Y vehicles were also offered to attendees after the presentation.<ref name="electrek-2019-03-14" /><ref name=Teslarati-2021>{{Cite web|url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-test-ride-video/ |title=Tesla Model Y test ride: first impressions of Tesla's latest 7-seat SUV (picture)|last=Alvarez|first=Simon |date=March 15, 2019|website=TESLARATI|language=en-US|access-date=March 15, 2019|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190330205313/https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-test-ride-video/ |archive-date=March 30, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> Due to its larger size, the Y consumes more energy than the 3, and thus has shorter range. The Fremont factory was changed to accommodate production of the Y.<ref name="ct2019-08-21">{{cite web |last1=Field |first1=Kyle |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20190821223314/https://cleantechnica.com/2019/06/08/streamlining-manufacturing-of-the-tesla-model-3-for-the-model-y/ |archive-date=August 21, 2019 |url-status=live |title=Streamlining Manufacturing of the Tesla Model 3 For The Model Y |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2019/06/08/streamlining-manufacturing-of-the-tesla-model-3-for-the-model-y/ |website=CleanTechnica |date=June 8, 2019 |access-date=April 27, 2023 |quote=the Model Y is notably larger than the Model 3 and has a larger frontal surface area as a result. Combined with its 8–10% heavier build, that will result in a lower efficiency than the 3}}</ref>

On March 13, 2020, Tesla made their first deliveries of the Model Y, along with publishing its owner's manual.<ref name=":0">{{cite news|url= https://electrek.co/2020/03/13/tesla-model-y-specs-we-finally-know-how-big-it-is/ |website= electrek.co |title= Tesla Model Y specs: we finally know how big it is |first= Jameson |last= Dow |date= March 13, 2020 |access-date= March 14, 2020}}</ref>

=== Changes ===
Vehicles manufactured from May 2021 lack lumbar support on passenger seats.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.team-bhp.com/news/tesla-drops-lumbar-support-feature-due-almost-no-usage |title=Tesla drops lumbar support feature due to 'almost no usage' |first=Rahul |last=Nagaraj |website=Team-BHP.com |date=2021-06-14 |access-date=2023-05-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2021/05/31/tesla-delivers-new-model-y-without-passenger-lumbar-support-why/ |title=Tesla delivers new Model Y without passenger lumbar support, and it's unclear why (update) |first=Fred |last=Lambert |date=May 31, 2021 |website=Electrek |access-date=2023-05-08}}</ref>

Vehicles manufactured from April 2021 no longer include radar for adaptive cruise control.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-uptick-crashes-accidents-elon-musk-removed-radar-autopilot-report-2023-3 |title=Tesla reportedly saw an uptick in crashes and mistakes after Elon Musk removed radar from its cars |first=Grace |last=Kay |work=Business Insider |location=US |date=2023-03-21 |access-date=2023-05-08}}</ref>

In early 2023, Tesla removed the ultrasonic parking sensors. Automated parking features relying only on the camera were shown to be unreliable.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.carexpert.com.au/car-news/tesla-removes-parking-sensors-to-save-money-the-results-are-predictably-terrible |title=Tesla removes parking sensors, its cars start running into things |first=Dev |last=Singh |website=CarExpert |location=Australia |date=2023-04-03 |access-date=2023-05-08}}</ref>

== Production ==
[[File:Tesla Model Y IMG 6822.jpg|thumb|Rear view]]{{expand section|article is oddly missing nearly all information on actual production since Model Y production began in 2020|date=July 2022}}
Tesla originally announced plans at the unveil to assemble the Model Y at [[Giga Nevada]] (in Sparks, Nevada), along with the battery and drivetrain for the vehicles, unlike the Model 3, where drivetrains and batteries are assembled at Giga Nevada, with final assembly completed at the [[Tesla Factory]] in [[Fremont, California]]. Two months later, in May 2019, Tesla said that they instead planned to shuffle production lines at the Tesla Fremont Factory to make space for Model Y production.<ref name="CNBC-2019-05-29">{{cite web |last1=Kolodny |first1=Lora |date=May 29, 2019 |title=Tesla is rejiggering its Fremont factory to build the Model Y SUV and a Model S refresh |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/29/tesla-fremont-factory-prepping-for-model-y-production-model-s-refresh.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190602063953/https://www.cnbc.com/2019/05/29/tesla-fremont-factory-prepping-for-model-y-production-model-s-refresh.html |archive-date=June 2, 2019 |access-date=June 3, 2019 |publisher=CNBC}}</ref>

On January 29, 2020, Tesla reported in its Q4 2019 earnings report that Model Y production had already started in the Fremont factory, that one can now place an order for their premium versions with all-wheel drive, and that delivery of Model Y would begin in Q1 2020.<ref name="2019-q4-ir">{{Cite web |title=Q4 and FY2019 Update |url=https://tesla-cdn.thron.com/static/O7WXQA_TSLA_Update_Letter_2019-4Q_BPWOH4.pdf |date=January 29, 2020 |access-date=February 27, 2020 |publisher=Tesla}}</ref>

In November 2019, Tesla announced that the Tesla Model Y would be the first vehicle to be assembled at the first European Gigafactory, [[Giga Berlin]].<ref name="electrek20191112">{{cite news |date=November 12, 2019 |title=Elon Musk: Tesla is going to build Gigafactory 4 in ‘Berlin area’ |first=Fred |last=Lambert |work=Electrek |url=http://electrek.co/2019/11/12/tesla-gigafactory-4-berlin-germany/ |url-status=live |access-date=April 4, 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191112210609/https://electrek.co/2019/11/12/tesla-gigafactory-4-berlin-germany/ |archive-date=November 12, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O8iEEVbhkR0&t=2490s |title=Die Verleihung des Goldenen Lenkrads 2019: Das sind die besten Autos des Jahres! |date=November 12, 2019 |publisher=AUTO BILD}}</ref>

United States deliveries started in March 2020 for the Long Range AWD version and the Performance version. Later in 2020, Tesla began shipping cars to the Canadian and Mexican markets.

Initial production of the made-in-China Model Y began in mid-December 2020 with 250,000 Model Y expected to be produced in 2021 in China alone.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla Model Y initial production begins in Gigafactory Shanghai |first=Simon |last=Alvarez |date=December 17, 2020 |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-production-begins-giga-shangha-video/ |website=Teslarati |access-date=April 27, 2023}}</ref><ref name="CarAndDriver-2019-03-15">{{cite magazine |last1=Capparella |first1=Joey |date=March 15, 2019 |title=The Tesla Model Y Is the All-Electric Brand's Entry into the Compact-Crossover Fray |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a26828716/tesla-model-y-photos-info/ |url-status=live |magazine=[[Car and Driver]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190403044043/https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a26828716/tesla-model-y-photos-info/ |archive-date=April 3, 2019 |access-date=March 14, 2019}}</ref> In November 2020, Tesla signed an agreement with [[LG Chem]] to supply battery cells for Model Y production in China.<ref name="LG Chem">{{cite web |last1=Merano |first1=Maria |date=November 23, 2020 |title=Tesla China signs contract with LG Chem for Model Y production |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-china-signs-contract-with-lg-chem-for-model-y-production/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201123203347/https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-china-signs-contract-with-lg-chem-for-model-y-production/ |archive-date=November 23, 2020 |access-date=November 23, 2020 |website=TESLARATI}}</ref>

On October 7, 2020, Musk tweeted that Giga Berlin Model Y would get single-piece rear and front frame cast, [[Structural battery|structural battery pack]], and new 4680 cells.<ref>{{Cite tweet|number=1313854912212750346|user=elonmusk|title=Giga Berlin Model Y will get single-piece rear and front frame cast|first=Elon|last=Musk|date=October 7, 2020|access-date=October 7, 2020|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=October 7, 2020 |title=Tesla Model Y from Giga Berlin will utilize 4680 cells and structural battery pack |first=Simon |last=Alvarez |access-date=April 27, 2023 |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-giga-berlin-4680-cells-structural-battery-pack-confirmed-elon-musk |website=Teslarati}}</ref>

On July 25, 2021, CEO Elon Musk revealed that Tesla was planning to release an updated design for the Model Y by the end of 2021. In addition, Tesla planned to implement their new structural battery pack to improve range. These new cars would be manufactured by the two new Tesla production facilities in Austin, Texas and Berlin, Germany. If Tesla was not able to roll out the new 4680 battery cells by the end of 2021, they would use the standard battery cells until the 4680's are ready.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.inverse.com/innovation/tesla-model-y-suv-redesign|title=Tesla Model Y: Elon Musk teases ‘new design’ to reach even more buyers|website=Inverse|first=Mike |last=Brown |date=August 2, 2021 | access-date=2023-04-27}}</ref>

=== Single-piece castings ===
{{See also|Giga Press}}
In August 2020, it was reported that the [[Tesla Factory]] in Fremont would soon activate the world's largest unibody casting machine for Model Y production, switching to casting the rear body in a single piece.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla Fremont to Soon Activate World's Largest Unibody Casting Machine in Mass Model Y Production |url=https://www.tesmanian.com/blogs/tesmanian-blog/tesla-model-y-from-fremont-will-soon-use-the-biggest-casting-machine-for-mass-production |website=Tesmanian |date=August 13, 2020 |first=Eva |last=Fox |access-date=2023-04-27}}</ref> Elon Musk told an interviewer that the Berlin-made Model Y is "not just a copy of the Model Y. It's actually a radical redesign of the core technology of building a car."<ref name="auto1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-redesign-giga-berlin-battery-cell-production-details-elon-musk-interview-video/|title=Elon Musk shares details on Tesla Model Y redesign, battery cell production in Giga Berlin |first=Simon |last=Alvarez |website=Teslarati |date=September 3, 2020 |access-date=2023-04-27}}</ref> With this new design and production method, rear and front portions of the frame will be a single-cast design. Injecting molten aluminum into a cast and having robots pull out the molded metal allowed Tesla to combine several manufacturing steps.<ref>{{Cite web |date=September 8, 2020 |title=Tesla bets on aluminum casting for German plant |url=https://europe.autonews.com/automakers/tesla-bets-aluminum-casting-german-plant |website=Automotive News Europe |agency=Reuters |access-date=2023-04-27 }}</ref> This manufacturing process is expected to result in significant cost savings, reducing a complex structural frame of dozens of parts, requiring many hours of welding to be reduced to just 1 part. Other savings include lower tool investments, reduced production time, lower number of robots, and a smaller production area.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Karosserie aus einem Guss: "Eine schöne und lohnenswerte Aufgabe" |url=https://www.fahrzeug-karosserie.de/karosserie-aus-einem-guss-eine-schoene-und-lohnenswerte-aufgabe-a-957640/ |website=Fahrzeug + Karosserie |first=Thomas |last=Günnel |language=de |date=August 21, 2020 |access-date=2023-04-27}}</ref>

In August 2020, Tesla started assembling the world’s biggest casting machine for this purpose, which the company called the [[Giga Press]]. The machine was supplied by Italian company IDRA.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Alvarez |first=Simon |date=2023-02-07 |title=Tesla Giga Press supplier IDRA teases new “Neo” die-casting machine |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-giga-press-idra-teases-neo-die-casting-machine-teaser/ |access-date=2023-04-05 |website=Teslarati |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=IDRA Group Builds Another 9,000-Ton Giga Press, Will Ship It To Asia |url=https://insideevs.com/news/630316/idra-group-builds-another-9000-ton-giga-press-will-ship-asia/ |date=January 10, 2023 |access-date=2023-04-05 |website=InsideEVs |first=Dan |last=Mihalascu |language=en}}</ref> Due to its unusually large size, the machine had to be assembled outside the factory under a carport-like structure.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=2020-08-15 |title=Tesla is installing world's biggest casting machine outside Fremont factory |url=https://electrek.co/2020/08/15/tesla-world-biggest-casting-machine-outside-fremont-factory/ |access-date=2023-04-05 |website=Electrek |language=en-US}}</ref>

With the new production method, the rear underbody section of the Model Y consists of only two large parts produced by the Giga Press, instead of 70 different metal parts for the Model 3.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=2021-01-11 |title=Tesla starts production of Model Y with massive single-piece rear casting |url=https://electrek.co/2021/01/11/tesla-starts-production-model-y-massive-single-piece-rear-casting/ |access-date=2023-04-05 |website=Electrek |language=en-US}}</ref>

== Technical details ==
[[File:Tesla Model 3 Screen Dec 2020.jpg|thumb|Center-mounted {{convert|15.4|in|cm|adj=on}} [[Liquid-crystal display|LCD]] [[touchscreen]],<ref name="dash">{{cite web |title=Tesla's Model 3 and Apple's iPhone have a few things in common |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/31/16067728/tesla-model-3-apple-iphone-comparison |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731170204/https://www.theverge.com/2017/7/31/16067728/tesla-model-3-apple-iphone-comparison |website=[[The Verge]] |first=Vlad |last=Savov |date=July 31, 2017 |archive-date=July 31, 2017 |access-date=August 1, 2017}}</ref> sporting the new UI design from Tesla's December 2020 "Holiday Update"<ref>{{Cite web |last=Merano |first=Maria |date=December 25, 2020 |title=Tesla rolls out 2020 Holiday Update: New Driving Visualizations, Supercharger Display Improvements and more (Release Notes) |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-holiday-update-2020-release-notes/ |access-date=April 30, 2021}}</ref>]]
=== Heat pump ===
The Model Y is Tesla's first car to use a [[heat pump]] instead of electric resistance for interior cabin heating.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=March 24, 2020 |title=Elon Musk: Tesla Model Y heat pump is some of the best engineering I've seen in a while |url=https://electrek.co/2020/03/23/tesla-model-y-heat-pump-elon-musk-best-engineering/ |access-date=March 25, 2020 |website=Electrek}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Erwin |first=Blane |date=March 26, 2020 |title=Model Y is the first Tesla with a heat pump. Here's why that's a big deal. |url=https://www.currentautomotive.com/model-y-is-the-first-tesla-with-a-heat-pump-heres-why-thats-a-big-deal/ |access-date=April 6, 2020 |website=Current Automotive}}</ref> Some electric vehicles from other manufacturers, including the [[Nissan Leaf]], [[Renault Zoe]], [[BMW i3|BMW i3 EV]], [[Jaguar I-Pace]], [[Audi e-tron (2018)|Audi e-tron]], and [[Kia Niro]], had already implemented heat pumps.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Can heat pumps solve cold-weather range loss for EVs? |url=https://www.greencarreports.com/news/1124387_can-heat-pumps-solve-cold-weather-range-loss-for-evs |first=Bengt |last=Halvorson |date=August 8, 2019 |access-date=March 25, 2020 |website=Green Car Reports}}</ref> In cold weather, the Model Y heat pump can be up to 300% more efficient than other Tesla cars' use of electric resistance heating.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla Model Y Heat Pump: Deep Dive and Closer Look |url=https://www.tesmanian.com/blogs/tesmanian-blog/tesla-model-y-heat-pump-range |first=Ma. |last=Claribelle Deveza |date=March 23, 2020 |access-date=March 25, 2020 |website=Tesmanian}}</ref> Because of this, the Model Y should be more energy efficient than other Tesla cars in cold weather.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web |last=Schmidt |first=Bridie |date=March 18, 2020 |title=Model Y has heat pump to solve issue of range in cold weather |url=https://thedriven.io/2020/03/18/model-y-has-heat-pump-to-solve-issue-of-range-in-cold-weather/ |access-date=March 25, 2020 |website=The Driven}}</ref> Electric cars can lose 40% or more of their range in cold weather (at ambient temperatures below {{Convert|20|F|C}}) when heating the interior cabin.<ref name="auto" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla and other electric car batteries lose 40% of their range in extremely cold weather: AAA |url=https://www.marketwatch.com/story/cold-weather-saps-electric-car-batteries-2019-02-07 |date=February 7, 2019 |access-date=March 25, 2020 |website=MarketWatch |agency=Associated Press}}</ref>

During his teardown of the Model Y,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Model Y Teardown |url=https://munrolive.com/model-y-teardown |website=Munrolive |first=Sandy |last=Munro}}</ref> auto analyst [[Sandy Munro]] found a component that has been referred to as the "octovalve", which appears to be the next iteration of the superbottle component used in the Model 3.<ref>{{cite web |last=Deveza |first=Ma. Claribelle |date=April 4, 2020 |title=Sandy Munro Finds Fun 'Octovalve' Tesla Model Y Easter Egg During Teardown |url=https://www.tesmanian.com/blogs/tesmanian-blog/tesla-model-y-easter-egg-octovalve-sandy-munro-teardown |access-date=April 18, 2020 |work=Tesmanian}}</ref> Musk has said that the new heat pump system/octovalve is one of the two most significant changes in the Model Y over the Model 3, the other being the new rear underbody [[casting]].<ref name="musk20200414">{{cite web |date=April 14, 2020 |title=Elon Musk discusses Model Y |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pih4kU6yvz8 |access-date=April 20, 2020 |work=Third Row Tesla |time=1:25–7:30}}</ref> The octovalve supports the Model Y heat pump as part of the car's thermal management system.<ref>{{cite web |last=Alvarez |first=Simon |date=April 5, 2020 |title=Tesla proudly hides 'Octovalve' insignia in Model Y, hints at next-gen thermal system |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-octovalve-easter-egg-teardown/ |access-date=April 18, 2020 |work=Teslarati}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Ruffo |first=Gustavo Henrique |date=April 6, 2020 |title=Tesla Octovalve Is The Video Sandy Munro Has Not Captured Yet |url=https://insideevs.com/news/408232/tesla-octovalve-sandy-munro-unshot-video/ |access-date=April 18, 2020 |work=InsideEVs}}</ref>

=== Radar ===
Vehicles produced since May 2021 lack [[radar]] for [[adaptive cruise control]].<ref name="c&d20220228">
{{cite web |first=Sebastian |last=Blanco |date=February 28, 2022 |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a39250157/tesla-no-radar-sensor-model-s-model-x/ |access-date=July 3, 2022 |title=Tesla Stops Putting Radar Sensors in New Model S and Model X EVs}}</ref> In February 2022, the [[National Highway Traffic Safety Administration]] opened an investigation over phantom braking in these new vehicles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-60432351|title=Tesla investigated over 'phantom braking' problem|date=February 18, 2022|publisher=BBC}}</ref>

Software update 2022.20.9 transitioned radar equipped Model Ys (and Model 3s) to Tesla Vision. Steering assist is limited to {{cvt|85|mph}} ({{cvt|90|mph}} previously with radar) and follow distance of "1" is no longer available, only 2 to 7

==Markets and configurations==
=== United States ===
During its introduction, there were four planned powertrain configurations for the Model Y in the U.S., which are Standard Range Rear-Wheel Drive (RWD), Long Range RWD, Long Range with Dual Motor All-Wheel Drive (AWD), and Performance (with Dual Motor All-Wheel Drive).<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla Press Information |url=https://www.tesla.com/presskit |access-date=November 10, 2020 |website=Tesla}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=2021 Tesla Model Y: Preview, Pricing, Release Date |url=https://www.carsdirect.com/2021/tesla/model-y |access-date=November 11, 2020 |website=CarsDirect}}</ref> {{As of|2023|April}}. the Long Range AWD model and the Performance model are currently being offered for public.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Design Your Model Y {{!}} Tesla |url=https://www.tesla.com/modely/design |access-date=March 27, 2020 |website=www.tesla.com |language=en}}</ref>

{| class="wikitable" style="float:right;"
!Timeline of Tesla Model Y in the U.S.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fosse |first=Paul |date=2022-12-24 |title=Outlook For Tesla Budget Buyers Has Changed Radically, & Predicted To Change Even More! |url=https://cleantechnica.com/2022/12/23/outlook-for-tesla-budget-buyers-has-changed-radically-predicted-to-change-even-more/ |access-date=2023-04-05 |website=CleanTechnica |language=en-US}}</ref>
|-

The Standard Range RWD configuration was initially canceled in July 2020 after being listed as to be announced in "spring 2021", due to the range ({{cvt|230|mi|km|disp=or}}) being unacceptably low to CEO [[Elon Musk]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla Cancels Sub $40,000 Standard Range Tesla Model Y |url=https://insideevs.com/news/433680/tesla-cancel-standard-range-tesla-model-y/ |date=July 13, 2020 |access-date=July 14, 2020 |first=Mark |last=Kane |website=InsideEVs |language=en}}</ref> On January 7, 2021, Tesla once again released the Standard Range RWD configuration, alongside the seven-seat option for the Model Y. The Standard Range RWD features {{convert|244|mi|abbr=out|0}} of [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]]-estimated range.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Merano |first=Maria |date=2021-01-08 |title=Tesla Model Y Standard Range trim, seven seat option now available |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-seven-seat-standard-range-price/ |access-date=2023-04-04 |website=TESLARATI |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=January 8, 2021 |title=Tesla launches Model Y with Standard Range RWD and 7-seat third-row option |first=Fred |last=Lambert |url=https://electrek.co/2021/01/07/tesla-model-y-standard-range-rwd-third-row-option |website=Electrek}}</ref> Tesla stopped taking orders for the variant in February 2021, making it the shortest-lived configuration offered for the Model Y.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=2021-02-21 |title=Tesla stops taking orders for cheapest Model Y in hard-to-follow updates |url=https://electrek.co/2021/02/21/tesla-stops-taking-orders-cheapest-model-y-updates/ |access-date=2023-04-04 |website=Electrek |language=en-US}}</ref>

After reports emerged in February 2021,<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last=Gurskiy |first=Denis |date=February 3, 2021 |title=It Looks Like Tesla Has Canceled the Long Range RWD Model Y |url=https://evbite.com/it-looks-like-tesla-has-canceled-the-long-range-rwd-model-y/ |access-date=February 3, 2021 |website=EVBite |language=en-US}}</ref> on December 6, 2021, Tesla formally notified customers who had pre-ordered the Long Range RWD that their chosen configuration is no longer available in the U.S. According to reports, this configuration was never delivered in the U.S.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |last=Mihalascu |first=Dan |date=December 6, 2021 |title=It's Official, Tesla Model Y Long Range RWD Not Going To Happen |url=https://insideevs.com/news/552675/tesla-modely-longrangerwd-officially-shelved/ |access-date=December 6, 2021 |website=InsideEVs |language=en-US}}</ref>

On April 9, 2022, Tesla introduced the Standard Range AWD configuration. Manufactured at [[Gigafactory Texas]], it is equipped with the new [[4680 battery]] cells and structural battery pack technology rated at {{convert|279|mi|abbr=out|0}} of EPA range.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=2022-04-12 |title=Tesla launches Model Y Standard Range AWD for employees starting at $60,000 and with a few upgrades |url=https://electrek.co/2022/04/12/tesla-launches-model-y-standard-range-employees-specs-price-upgrades/ |access-date=2023-04-04 |website=Electrek |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Report: Made-in-Texas Tesla Model Y Starts At $59,990 |url=https://insideevs.com/news/579535/report-mit-tesla-modely-59990-price/ |date=April 12, 2022 |access-date=2023-04-04 |first=Mark |last=Kane |website=InsideEVs |language=en}}</ref> This configuration is an "off-the-menu" model, as it is only available for internal employees, invited reservation holders, and customers residing in the [[Texas]] area.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=2022-05-18 |title=Tesla starts to offer Giga Texas Model Y to some customers for faster delivery |url=https://electrek.co/2022/05/18/tesla-offer-giga-texas-model-y-some-customers/ |access-date=2023-04-04 |website=Electrek |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla Offering New Model Y AWD With 4680 Cells, Accelerated Delivery |url=https://insideevs.com/news/586630/tesla-modely-standard-range-awd-4680-delivery/ |date=May 18, 2022 |access-date=2023-04-04 |website=InsideEVs |first=Steven |last=Loveday |language=en}}</ref>

On January 12, 2023, Tesla announced a significant price reduction for the Model Y and Model 3. This reduction made the Model Y Long Range eligible for the federal tax credit of $7,500 under the [[Inflation Reduction Act]], which is applicable only for cars that are priced below $55,000.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Merano |first=Maria |date=2023-01-13 |title=Breaking: Tesla reduces Model 3 and Model Y prices in the United States |url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-3-model-y-price-cut-united-states-update/ |access-date=2023-04-04 |website=TESLARATI |language=en-US}}</ref>

Around April 7, 2023, Tesla introduced the Model Y All-Wheel-Drive (or sometimes simply "Model Y")<ref name="ie-y-awd">{{cite news |last=Loveday |first=Steven |date=2023-04-10 |title=Tesla Offering New, Cheaper Version Of Model Y |url=https://insideevs.com/news/661535/new-tesla-modely-available-in-us-cheaper/ |work=InsideEVs |access-date=2023-04-10}}</ref> configuration for sale to the general public.<ref name="et-y-awd">{{cite news |last=Lambert |first=Fred |date=2023-04-07 |title=Tesla opens orders on cheaper $50,000 Model Y with 4680 cells |url=https://electrek.co/2023/04/07/tesla-opens-orders-cheaper-model-y-4680-cells/ |work=Electrek |access-date=2023-04-10}}</ref><ref name="at-y-awd">{{cite news |last=Gitlin |first=Jonathan |date=2023-04-07 |title=Tesla drops its prices once again this year |url=https://arstechnica.com/cars/2023/04/tesla-drops-its-prices-once-again-this-year/ |work=[[Ars Technica]] |access-date=2023-04-10 |quote=And unlike earlier this year, you can now order a standard range Model Y, which costs $49,990 before any options.}}</ref> This configuration uses [[4680 battery]] cells and is based on the previous Standard Range AWD configuration which was not available to the general public.<ref name="et-y-awd"/>

=== Canada ===
In April 2023, Tesla began producing made-in-China Model Y to be sold in Canada.<ref>{{Cite news |last= |date=2023-04-24 |title=Exclusive: Tesla readies export of Model Y to Canada from China |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/autos-transportation/tesla-readies-export-model-y-canada-china-source-memo-2023-04-24/ |access-date=2023-04-24}}</ref>

=== Australia ===
Orders for the Model Y in Australia opened in June 10, 2022, with initial configurations offered were RWD and Performance AWD and imported from [[Gigafactory Shanghai]]. Deliveries commenced in August 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla Delivers First Model Y In Australia and New Zealand |url=https://insideevs.com/news/604969/tesla-delivers-modely-australia-new-zealand/ |access-date=2023-04-04 |date=Aug 17, 2022 |first=Mark |last=Kane |website=InsideEVs |language=en}}</ref> The Long Range AWD configuration was released on April 4, 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-04-04 |title=New price cuts for 2023 Tesla Model 3 and Model Y electric cars in Australia |url=https://www.drive.com.au/news/tesla-model-3-model-y-price-cuts-april-2023/ |access-date=2023-04-04 |website=Drive |first=Ben |last=Zachariah |language=en-AU}}</ref>

=== China ===
On June 5, 2020, Tesla launched the Model Y Online design studio for the Chinese market, allowing customers in China to place orders for the upcoming made-in-China Model Y.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tesla Launches Model Y Online Design Studio For Chinese Market |url=https://insideevs.com/news/427178/tesla-model-y-online-design-studio-china/ |date=June 5, 2020 |access-date=April 27, 2023 |first=Mark |last=Kane |website=InsideEVs}}</ref> First delivery of the model was made on January 18, 2021.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Moss |first=Trefor |date=January 18, 2021 |title=Tesla Starts Delivering China-Made Model Y Crossover |language=en-US |work=The Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/tesla-starts-delivering-china-made-model-y-crossover-11610966805 |access-date=January 19, 2021 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

On January 1, 2021, Tesla started selling the Model Y in China, and it sold out its planned production (an unknown quantity) for Q1 2021 within 6 days.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Insights |first=Benzinga EV |date=January 6, 2021 |title=Tesla Sells Out Of Q1 Supply Of Model Y In China Just Days After Opening Order Page: Report |url=https://www.benzinga.com/tech/21/01/19042173/tesla-sells-out-of-q1-supply-of-model-y-in-china-just-days-after-opening-order-page-report |access-date=January 9, 2021 |website=Benzinga |language=en}}</ref>

==Reception==

The Model Y has been generally very well received. Critics laud the car's appearance, quick acceleration, spacious interior and range. The clumsy handling and stiff ride are often touted as improvement points.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/tesla/model-y |title=2023 Tesla Model Y |first=Drew |last=Dorian |work=Car and Driver |date=December 20, 2022 |location=US |access-date=2023-01-28}}</ref> 
According to Top Gear, the Model Y is a "great car to live with".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.topgear.com/car-reviews/tesla/model-y |title=Tesla Model Y review 2023 |work=Top Gear |location=UK |date=December 30, 2022 |access-date=2023-01-28}}</ref> The Model Y is also touted as the sales leader in its class <ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.edmunds.com/tesla/model-y/ |title=2023 Tesla Model Y |first=Nick |last=Yekikian |work=Edmunds |location=US |access-date=2023-01-28}}</ref> but competition is rising with numerous alternatives hitting the market from other manufacturers.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.topgear.com/videos/electric-awards-2022/top-gears-big-electric-crossover-test-tesla-model-y-vs-rivals |title=Top Gear's big electric crossover test: Tesla Model Y vs rivals |work=Top Gear |location=UK |date=April 15, 2022 |access-date=2023-01-28}}</ref>

On September 8, 2020, Volkswagen Group Chairperson of the Board of Management, [[Herbert Diess]], wrote about the Model Y: "This car is for us in many aspects (not in all!) a reference: user experience, updatability, driving features, performance of the top of the range models, charging network, range. Big advantage: Model Y was/is thought through as an electric car – as is the [[Volkswagen ID.3|ID.3]]. Many of our competitors still using their ICE platforms. The result: They aren’t getting the best EVs."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-model-y-review-vw-herbert-diess-insights/|title=Tesla Model Y leaves strong impression on VW's Herbert Diess after test drive|first=Simon|last=Alvarez|website=Teslarati|date=September 8, 2020 |access-date=April 27, 2023}}</ref>
